answers.answer: Hello - thanks for asking your question.Here is a list of disorders that can result in an elevated alkaline phosphatase.  You may want to discuss these possibilities with your personal physician.Marked elevation:- Obstructive jaundice due to cancer- Common duct stones- Sclerosing cholangitis- Bile duct stricture- Drug and toxins associated with cholestasis- Primary biliary cirrhosis- Liver allograft rejection- Infectious hepatobiliary diseases seen in patients with AIDS (eg, CMV or microsporidiosis and tuberculosis with hepatic involvement).- Alcohol-induced steatonecrosis (rarely)Here are some other causes that result in disproportional elevation:- Partial bile duct obstruction due to gallstones or tumor.- Infiltrative diseases such as amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hepatic abscesses, tuberculosis, and metastatic carcinoma.- Extrahepatic diseases such as myeloid metaplasia, peritonitis, diabetes mellitus, subacute thyroiditis, and uncomplicated gastric ulcer.- Extrahepatic tumors, including osteosarcomas, lung, gastric, head and neck, renal cell carcinoma, ovarian, uterine cancer, and Hodgkin's disease, that secrete alkaline phosphatase.Followup with your personal physician is essential.This answer is not intended as and does not substitute for medical advice - the information presented is for patient education only. Please see your personal physician for further evaluation of your individual case.Thanks,Kevin, M.D.
Is there a physician that can answer my question that I posted July 15, 2003 regarding my mother's elevated alkaline phosphatase.  Thank you.  GCH

Thank you Kevin, M.D. for your response.  This is very helpful.  If, for example, this elevated status was due to drugs and toxic reaction--are there specific drugs that you could list for me to be aware of.My mother had annual physicals--general practioner, gynocologist and all reports were fine--approximately 4 months ago.  Therefore, I could not imagine what might be the underlying cause for such high elevation that would have not been detected 4 months ago.Do you have any further comments or information regardins this.  I would appreciate any addtional comments.GCH

question: Hello,  My mother is 90 years old.  She recently had a blood test that indicated extreme elevation of alkaline phosphatase. The test show 1118 IU/L, ALP, Headted 429 IU/L % activity remaining 38%--%activity remaining of 20% or less suggests that the predominant fraction is of osteoblastic origin.  Activity remaining of 25 - 55% suggest that the predominant fraction is of hepatic origin.  She is scheduled for a CAT scan of her abdomen this week.My understanding is that normal range is 30-120 U/L.  I have also been told normal range is 44 - 147 IU/L.  On the lab form it stated 39-117 for females.  Regardless--the elevation is EXTREMELY HIGH at 1118 IU/L!!I am greatly concerned and would like to know what this might mean.  My mother takes medicines that includes, predisone 5mg, Nexum, Reglan--I need to get list of all.PLEASE GIVE ME INFORMATION ON THIS MATTER.  Thank you.  GCH
title: Elevated Levels of Alkaline Phosphatase
